title: Models of computation and running time
content:
A problem with finite inputs isn't really interesting. We could pre-compute the desired output, put it in a hash, and then $O(1)$.

![](image-kjvqcyjl.png)

Every model of Computation is wrong, but some are useful. LMAO this is getting over-used. :joy:.


## Models of Computation

1. Pseudo-code
![](image-kjvsoowl.png)

So, a runtime might be $O(n)$ arithmetically, but keep in mind that an implementation can't represent infinitely large integers. There are overflows to worry about.

![](image-kjvstcx7.png)

2. Random Access Machine

![](image-kjvsxeci.png)

So just assume that indexes and the like can fit into one machine word, constant time for all computations.

3. Circuit Family -> goes all the way down to hardware :face_vomiting:
4. Turing machine -> Time to access memory location $i$ is proportional to $i$.

The model is very important; it changes the running time of algorithms. Be careful which one is assumed, and what assumptions we're making. We will be using **word RAM** model.


![](image-kjvt8n0x.png)

Worst-case is the most important because we want a guarantee.

![](image-kjvteigd.png)
Of course, Big-O is **worst case upper bound**.

Here are some properties:

$$O(f(n)+g(n)) => O(max\{f(n), g(n)\})$$  
This rule is tricky. There could be $n$ where $f$ dominates, and some where $g$ dominates.

Big O is also transitive, so 
$$f(n) \in O(g(n)), g(n) \in O(h(n)) \implies f(n) \in O(h(n))$$

![](image-kjvtndal.png)


Tight bounds ($\Theta$) are good for comparisons. We can't say that $O(n \log n)$ is better than $O(n^2)$, because that's not specific enough.
